Situation1: They notice minor inconsistencies in a building plan that are unlikely to cause immediate issues.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread before me, red pen in hand. As an architect, I’m trained to spot even the smallest inconsistencies—today, I noticed a few in the new community center’s plans. They’re minor, unlikely to cause immediate problems, but my professional code nags at me: safety and compliance come first. I should stay, review every line, and make sure nothing slips through.

My phone buzzes. It’s David from the synagogue. There’s a funeral prayer in an hour, and they’re short one person for the minyan. He asks if I can come. As a Jew, I know how important it is to help form the quorum, especially for a mourner’s prayer. The community expects me to be there, to uphold tradition and support those in grief.

I look at the clock, then back at the plans. If I leave now, I’ll have to rush my review, risking a mistake. If I stay, the minyan will fall short, and someone will be denied the comfort of communal prayer. My chest tightens as I weigh the demands—my duty to safety, my duty to faith—each pulling me in a different direction.
